title: Ticket #7870: Read IDTOKENS files for daemons as root, not condor
description:
The files containing daemon credentials are currently expected to be owned by the canonical 'condor' user in /etc/condor. This ticket proposes changing them to be owned by root.

One advantage of having them owned by condor is that the admin is probably logged in as the condor user when if running condor_token_create and so it's natural to create a file as that same user.

However, in almost all other cases (KERBEROS, GSI, SSL, MUNGE, and even PASSWORD) the daemon credentials are owned by root and not readable by the condor user. For security and consistency I think IDTOKENS should be the same. If the admin is relying on HTCondor's "bootstrap" mode to have daemons auto-generate token requests and then store the tokens, this can be done as root as well, so I don't believe the burden on the administrator is a problem.

If there are other pros and cons please add them to this description.
